    to save the documents:
    cData  := Crypt( cData, cPW)
    memowrit( cArgs, cData  )

could it be ?

Two-state key/value shared object caching
    The shared object cache API (socache) and its provider modules provide a server wide key/value based shared object cache. These modules are designed to cache low level data such as SSL sessions and authentication credentials. Backends allow the data to be stored server wide in shared memory, or datacenter wide in a cache such as memcache or distcache.
<https://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.4/caching.html>

Error: Unknown or unregistered symbol

PEEKBYTE()   Reads a byte from memory
PEEKSTR()   Reads a byte sequence from memory
PEEKWORD()   Reads a 16-bit word from memory


POKEBYTE()   Writes a byte to memory
POKEWORD()   Writes a 16-bit word to memory
PPCBUFTYP()   Determines the communication buffer type


? PEEKBYTE(1000, 2000)       // Segment 1000d, Offset 2000d
The AT BIOS copyright is found at the F000:0h address.  Therefore, each
byte is repeated and CharOdd() is used to display it.  It reads to the
first Chr(0):

? CharOdd(PEEKSTR("F000", 0))      // "19xx, 19xx Copyright...."
but I get Error: Unknown or unregistered symbol

<@UJHD6A81H>

I like how we can work with PRG without compile and run it but I think that it should be used ONLY for developerment. for production you should compile and use it as HRB
then you will protect your informations because it can not be read :slightly_smiling_face:
(If I understand the question correct it is the solution)
<@UJHD6A81H> I’m arriving late to the party, but about your concerns to password storage, let me tell sth: passwords should be stored using sth like HB_MD5 or better, HB_SHA256()
Given a password, in the table it should be stored as REPLACE password with HB_SHA256( cPassword + cSalt ) , where cSalt is a constant used in the whole system for encryption
In this way, when a user logs in the password can be checked applying the same function (HB_SHA256+salt) and check if it is the same
With this, if someone gets the data from the table, the contents of the passwords field is absolutely useless

Regarding the concerns about the systems security, let me set an analogy with our home security: You don’t want anybody to get to your house, neither your bedrooms, bathroom, office, etc. but you put the safety *in your doors and windows*.
The same happens in your server: the access to the server should be controlled and limited. The access to data should be done by spected procedures and methods.

Respecto de las sesiones: Hasta donde conozco, la sesion tiene dos partes: una parte almacenada en una cookie del cliente/browser, con cuyo contenido identifico algo en el almacenamiento del servidor (archivo, fichero, registro en una tabla, etc) que tiene los datos con los que identifico ese cliente en el servidor.
Supongamos que lo que guardamos en la sesion será un hash

Cuando un cliente se loguea, genero una string aleatoria larga, digamos de 128 bytes. esa cadena sera la cookie, luego la primera mitad puede ser el nombre de un fichero en el que guardamos el HB_CRYPT(HB_SERIALIZE( cHash ), cClave ) donde cClave es la segunda mitad de la cadena.
EN cuanto se pierda la cookie el fichero sera irrecuperable, la clave para desencriptar el fichero solo vive en la cookie.
Y nada me impediría cambiar la cookie (y por lo tanto la clave del fichero) en cada llamada

Para las sesiones seguimos teniendo el problema que en el servidor, si lo usan varios usuarios estos pueden acceder a los ficheros, borrarlos, modificarlos,....Aun no sabemos como solucionar este tema
si estan encriptados como te comentaba, no deberia ser problema.
Y si hay alguien que puede borrar o leer tus ficheros, tu problema no son las cookies
Tu problema es que hay alguien leyendo ficheros del servidor
Si hay el problema Carlos. Si el server lo usan varias cuentas y estas pueden acceder a los ficheros
Bueno pues se trata de impedir q solo el responsable de la cuenta pueda acceder a estos ficheros
El problema es que hay gente con malas intenciones en el servidor.
Pues mientras no sepamos como proteger de estas malas intenciones aun no se pueden poner las sesiones

Buenos dias !
good morning

Otto, While I am not sure about the security of a file in the hosting (this means that from any prg you can manipulate any of these) my recommendation is that you use JWT.

You do not need to store any keys on the server in memory. Current systems validate a user and they are given credentials to use the web. These credentials can be used in many ways, but the most popular way today is the use of Json Web Token.

You can send this token from the server as you want, even if you want to put it inside a cookie.

When you receive this token again you will only have to validate if this token is authentic
And you don't have to have any keys stored for this.
Traducire el post porque me parece interesante...

Mientras yo no tenga claro la seguridad de un fichero en el hosting (esto quiere decir que desde un prg se pueda manipular cualquiera de estos) mi recomendacion es que uses JWT.
Tu no necesitas almacenar ninguna clave en el servidor en memoria. Los sitemas actuales validan un usuario y se le da a este unas credenciales para poder usar la web. Estas credenciales pueden usarse de muchas maneras,  pero la manera mas popular hoy en dia es el uso de Json Web Token.

Puedes enviar desde el servidor este token como quieras , incluso si tu deseas ponerlo hasta dentro de una cookie.

Cuando recibas de nuevo este token tu solo habra de validar si este token es autentico
Y tu no tendras que almacenar claves en memoria  para esto

text: Buon giorno!
Buenas Carlos :slightly_smiling_face:
En realidad instalar mod_harbour para IIS es mucho más sencillo que para Apache...
increible pero cierto...

There are not safe methods to handle simultaneous request from different threads in memory. Also the memory contents gets lost on failure/restart. I read you use in php some functions to use memory, you can read in PHP’s website about those functions in the comments. A safe way to use memory is through the use of some kind of service, like Redis. Redis is very popular, it is used for caching, temp storage, etc. It also has persistency.
Yes, I use MariaDb/MySQL _a lot_, and rely in their databases for authentication.

Regarding passwords, no problem. The use of HB_Sha256+Salt make almost impossible to recover password, even with access to the source code. HB_SHA256 is a one way encryption, so there is no reasonable method of password recovery.
Carlos, necesitamos tu ayuda :slightly_smiling_face:

If Someone steals your PC, your security problems are are your premesis, not your server. With an encrypted filesystem, it would be enough to avoid hard disk reading. I think Windows Server has such encription, Linux does. Anyway, let’s put our effort (and fears) at the right place. AFAIK, you install your app in a Win server and access it from Remote Desktop. What happen if someone steals that PC?
